Subject: Re: [junit] What is expected behavior on Assert.assertEquals on Number object?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=341876227; y=JveKYo39t6r98J5BzvKZrBjEZlAuNHCjdQjjr_AXCCM
X-Yahoo-Profile: dsaff

If anyone's curious, the bug was actually caused while trying to fix
something else.  This was a battle of conversions.  By taking
advantage of auto-boxing, we lost the advantage of automatic widening.
 While trying to simulate widening after auto-boxing, I did something
dumb.  Thanks to Eclipse, the dumb decision was immortalized for over
a year.  Summary:

assertEquals(1, 1L)
4.2: false
4.3: true
4.4: true

assertEquals(1.2, 1.3)
4.2: false
4.3: true
4.4: exception thrown: use three-argument version

   David Saff

On Mon, Jun 23, 2008 at 5:03 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> On Tue, Jun 3, 2008 at 11:41 PM, Nattapong Sirilappanich
> <natta@...> wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> Hi,
>>
>> When i try to make an assertion on Number object, e.g. Double the result
>> always assertion successful.
>> Even i try to compare by org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(123456789.345,
>> 123456789.34), it still success. (I'm expecting failure)
>
>
> Sorry to have come late to the conversation.  My last five attempts to
> mail the list have failed.
>
> JUnit 4.3 has a bug.  1.2 should never equal 1.3.  Eclipse 3.3 shipped
> with JUnit 4.3, which is why this bug has had such a long lifespan.
> You can upgrade to JUnit 4.4, wait for Eclipse 3.4, or use
> assertEquals(double, double, double) directly.
>
>   David Saff
>
